title: 111_hr2679
content: SECTION 1. E-VERIFY PROGRAM. The Employee Verification Amendment Act of 2009 extends the E-Verify program until September 30, 2014. It also ensures funding for the Social Security Administration's responsibilities related to immigration reform. The Employee Verification Amendment Act of 2009 extends the E-Verify program until September 30, 2014 and provides funding for the Social Security Administration's responsibilities related to immigration reform, including acquiring and maintaining necessary technological equipment and systems for the Commissioner's responsibilities under section 404 of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996. The Employee Verification Amendment Act of 2009 extends the E-Verify program and provides funding for the Social Security Administration's responsibilities related to immigration reform. The agreement requires quarterly advance funds based on estimating methodology, annual accounting, and reconciliation of actual costs incurred. The agreement between the Commissioner and the Secretary of Homeland Security for funding under the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 shall be deemed in effect on an interim basis for any fiscal year if the required agreement has not been reached by October 1, with adjustments for inflation and changes in the volume of requests under the basic pilot confirmation system. The pilot confirmation system requires an interim agreement if not reached by October 1. The Commissioner and the Secretary must notify relevant committees of the failure to reach the agreement and provide updates every 90 days until an agreement is reached. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on erroneous tentative nonconfirmations under the basic pilot confirmation system established by the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996. The study will analyze the causes of these errors. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on erroneous tentative nonconfirmations under the basic pilot confirmation system to analyze causes of errors and their effects on individuals, employers, and Federal agencies. A report will be submitted to relevant committees within 2 years of the Act's enactment. Additionally, a GAO study on the effects of the Basic Pilot on small entities will be conducted within the same timeframe. The Comptroller General will submit a report to the House and Senate Judiciary Committees analyzing the effects of the basic pilot program on small entities, detailing compliance costs, enrollment numbers, and projected reporting requirements. The Comptroller General will submit a report to analyze the effects of the basic pilot program on small entities, including compliance costs, enrollment numbers, reporting requirements, factors impacting enrollment, and steps taken to minimize economic impact. The report will cover direct and indirect effects separately, such as wages, time, fees, cash flow, sales, and competitiveness. The report will provide specific details on small businesses with fewer than 50 employees and small entities in states mandating the basic pilot program. The EB-5 Regional Center Pilot Program is amended to set aside 3,000 visas annually through fiscal year 2014. The Special Immigrant Nonminister Religious Worker Program extends the deadline to September 30, 2014. The waiver of foreign country residence requirement for international medical graduates is addressed. Section 220(c) of the Immigration and Nationality Technical Corrections Act of 1994 is amended to change the deadline from "September 30, 2009" to "September 30, 2014".
